content: SEC. 101. Extension of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through March 31, 2004. Activities authorized by part A of title IV of the Social Security Act, and by sections 510, 1108(b), and 1925, shall continue through March 31, 2004, with necessary appropriations. Conforming amendments are made for supplemental grants in certain states. Amendments are made to various sections of the Social Security Act, changing dates from 2003 to 2004 and adding provisions for fiscal year 2005. SEC. 102 extends the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority through March 31, 2004, with necessary appropriations. SEC. 201 amends the Internal Revenue Code to disclose return information for income contingent repayment of student loans until December 31, 2004. SEC. 202 extends Internal Revenue Service user fees under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees for requests to the IRS for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters. Fees will vary based on categories, be determined by request complexity, and must be paid in advance. Exemptions and reduced fees will be provided as deemed appropriate, with an exemption for certain pension plan determination letter requests. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees for requests to the IRS for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters, with exemptions for certain pension plan determination letter requests. During the fifth plan year of a pension benefit plan's existence, or at the end of any remedial amendment period within the first 5 plan years. The text discusses definitions and rules related to pension benefit plans, eligible employers, and average fees charged. Eligible employers must have at least one non-highly compensated employee participating in the plan. Requests for prototype plans intended for marketing purposes are excluded from fee calculations. The average fee charged under the program required by subsection (a) shall not be less than the amount determined under the following table for employee plan ruling and opinion. The IRS imposes various fees for different services, ranging from $200 to $350. No fee is charged for requests made after December 31, 2004. Additionally, a new item is added to the table of sections for chapter 77 of the Code related to Internal Revenue Service user fees. The Revenue Act of 1987 and the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 are repealed. Fees collected under section 7528 of the Internal Revenue Code must be approved by an appropriations Act before being spent by the IRS. The amendments apply to requests made after the enactment of this Act. COBRA fees are extended to March 31, 2004, and Medicare cost-sharing is extended for certain qualifying individuals. The Social Security Act is amended to extend COBRA fees and Medicare cost-sharing for qualifying individuals until March 31, 2004. Total allocation amounts for fiscal years 2002 and 2003 are adjusted accordingly. The Social Security Act is amended to extend COBRA fees and Medicare cost-sharing for qualifying individuals until March 31, 2004, with a total allocation amount of $100,000,000 for that period. SEC. 402 extends the provision equalizing urban and rural standardized Medicare inpatient hospital payments. The provision equalizing urban and rural standardized Medicare inpatient hospital payments is extended until March 31, 2004. The Secretary of Health and Human Services has the authority to delay implementation if necessary, but not later than November 1, 2003. The Secretary has the authority to delay implementation of the amendments made to Medicare inpatient hospital payments until November 1, 2003. If there is a delay, adjustments will be made to ensure total payments for inpatient hospital services in fiscal year 2004 remain the same. These adjustments will not affect payment rates for services after September 30, 2004. The Secretary can administer these provisions without the need for rulemaking or notice. The Secretary has the authority to delay Medicare inpatient hospital payment amendments until November 1, 2003. No rulemaking or notice is required for the Secretary to carry out this authority. There is no administrative or judicial review allowed for any delays or determinations made by the Secretary under this provision.
